Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XIII. THE PEWTERERES AND FOUNDOURS. Joseph's trouble about Mary. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Joseph. Maria. Prima Puella. Secunda Puella. Angelus.]

[Scene, Joseph wandering in the wilderness; his house at one side.] 1. Jos. Of grete mornyng may I me mene, And walk full werily be Ã¾is way, For nowe Ã¾an wende I best hase bene Att ease and reste by reasonne ay. For I am of grete elde, Wayke and al vnwelde, Als ilke man se it maye; I may nowder buske ne belde, But owther in frith or felde; For shame what sall I saie 2. That Ã¾us-gates nowe on myne alde dase Has wedded a yonge wenche to my wiff, And may no?t wele tryne over two strase! Nowe lorde! how langes all I lede Ã¾is liff, My banes er heuy als lede, And may no?t stande in stede, Als kende it is full ryfe. Now lorde! Ã¾ou me wisse and rede, Or sone me dryue to dede, Ãou may best stynte Ã¾is striffe. 3. For bittirly Ã¾an may I banne The way I in Ã¾e temple wente, Itt was to me a bad barganne, For reuthe I may it ay repente. For Ã¾are-in was ordande Vn-wedded men sulde stande, Al 'sembled at asent; And ilke ane a drye wande On heght helde in his hand, And I ne wist what it ment. 4. In-mange al othir ane bare I, Itt florisshed faire, and floures on sprede, And they saide to me for-thy Ãat with a wiffe I sulde be wedde. Ãe bargayne I made Ã¾are, Ãat rewes me nowe full sare, So am I straytely sted. Now castes itt me in care, For wele I myght euere mare Anlepy life haue led. 5. Hir werkis me wyrkis my wonges to wete, I am begiled; how, wate I no?t. My ?onge wiffe is with childe full grete, Ãat makes me nowe sorowe vnsoght. Ãat reproffe nere has slayne me! For-thy giff any man frayne me How Ã¾is Ã¾ing may be wroght, To gabbe yf I wolde payne me, Ãe lawe standis harde agayne me, To dede I mon be broght. 6. And lathe me thinkeÃ¾, on Ã¾e todir syde, My wiff with any man to defame, And whethir of there twa Ã¾at I bide I mon no?t scape withouten schame. Ãe childe certis is noght myne, Ãat reproffe dose me pyne, And gars me fle fra hame. My liff gif I shuld tyne, Sho is a clene virgine For me, withouten blame. 7. But wele I wate thurgh prophicie, A maiden clene suld bere a childe, But it is nought sho, sekirly, For-thy I wate I am begiled. And why ne walde som yonge man ta her, For certis I thynke ouer-ga hir Into som wodes wilde, Thus thynke I to stele fra hir, God childe ther wilde bestes sla hir, She is so meke and mylde. 8. Of my wendyng wil I none warne, Neuere Ã¾e lees it is myne entente To aske hir who gate hir Ã¾at barne, ?itt wolde I witte fayne or I wente. [Enters his house. All hayle! God be here-inne! i Puella. Welcome, by Goddis dere myght! Jos. Whare is Ã¾at ?onge virgine, Marie, my berde so bright? 9. i Puella. Certis, Joseph, ?e sall vndirstande, Ãat sho is not fulle farre you fra, Sho sittis at hir boke full faste prayand For ?ou and us, and for all Ã¾a Ãat oght has nede. But for to tell hir will I ga Of youre comyng, withouten drede. [Goes to Mary. Haue done! and rise vppe, dame, And to me take gud hede, Joseph, he is comen hame. Maria. Welcome! als God me spede. 10. Dredles to me he is full dere, Joseph my spouse, welcome er yhe! Jos. Gramercy, Marie, saie what chere, Telle me Ã¾e soth, how es't with Ã¾e? Wha has ben there? Thy wombe is waxen grete, thynke me, Ãou arte with barne, allas! for care! A! maidens, wa worthe ?ou! Ãat lete hir lere swilke lare. ii Puella. Joseph, ?e sall no?t trowe, In hir no febill fare. 11. Jos. Trowe it noght arme! lefe wenche, do way! Hir sidis shewes she is with childe. Whose is't Marie? Mar. Sir, Goddis and youres. Jos. Nay, nay, now wate I wele I am begiled. And resonne why With me flesshely was Ã¾ou neuere fylid, And I forsake it here for-thy. Say, maidens, how es Ã¾is? Tels me Ã¾e soÃ¾e, rede I, And but ?e do, i-wisse, Ãe bargayne sall ?e aby. 12. ii Puella. If ?e threte als faste as yhe can, Ãare is noght to saie Ã¾ere till, For trulye her come neuer noman, To waite her body with non ill, Of this swete wight. For we haue dwelt ay with her still, And was neuere fro hir day nor nyght. Hir kepars haue we bene and sho ay in oure sight, Come here no man bytwene to touche Ã¾at berde so bright. 13. i Puella. Na, here come noman in Ã¾ere wanes, And Ã¾at euere witnesse will we, Saue an Aungell ilke a day anes, With bodily foode hir fedde has he, Othir come nane. Wharfore we ne wate how it shulde be, But thurgh Ã¾e haly gaste allone. For trewly we trowe Ã¾is, is grace with hir is gone, For sho wroght neuere no mys, we witnesse euere ilkane. 14. Jos. Ãanne se I wele youre menyng is, Ãe Aungell has made hir with childe. Nay, som man in aungellis liknesse With somkyn gawde has hir begiled; And Ã¾at trow I. For-thy nedes noght swilke wordis wilde At carpe to me dissayuandly. We! why gab ye me swa and feynes swilk fantassy, Allas! me is full wa! for dule why ne myght I dy. 15. To me Ã¾is is a carefull cas, Rekkeles I raffe, reste is my rede, I dare loke no man in Ã¾e face, Derfely for dole why ne were I dede. Me lathis my liff! In temple and in othir stede Ilke man till hethyng will me dryff. Was neuer wight sa wa, for ruthe I all to ryff, Allas! why wrought Ã¾ou swa, Marie! my weddid wiffe? 16. Mar. To my witnesse grete God I call, Ãat in mynde wroght neuere no mysse. Jos. Whose is Ã¾e childe Ã¾ou arte with-all? Mar. Youres sir, and Ã¾e kyngis of blisse. Jos. Ye, and hoo Ã¾an? Na, selcouthe tythandis than is Ã¾is, Excuse Ã¾am wele there women can. But Marie, all Ã¾at sese Ã¾e may witte Ã¾i werkis ere wan, Thy wombe all way it wreyes Ã¾e, Ã¾at Ã¾ou has mette with man. 17. Whose is it? als faire mot ye be-fall. Mar. Sir, it is youres and Goddis will. Jos. Nay, I ne haue noght a-do with-all. Neme it na more to me, be still! Ãou wate als wele as I, Ãat we two same flesshly Wroght neuer swilk werkis with ill. Loke Ã¾ou dide no folye Be-fore me preuely Thy faire maydenhede to spill. 18. But who is Ã¾e fader? telle me his name, Mar. None but youre selfe. Jos. Late be, for shame. I did it neuere, Ã¾ou dotist dame, by bukes and belles, Full sakles shulde I bere Ã¾is blame aftir Ã¾ou telles. For I wroght neuere in worde nor dede, Thyng Ã¾at shulde marre thy maydenhede, To touche me till. For of slyk note war litill nede, Yhitt for myn awne I wolde it fede, Might all be still. 19. Ãarfore Ã¾e fadir tell me, Marie. Mar. But God and yhow, I knowe right none. Jos. A! slike sawes mase me full sarye, With grete mornyng to make my mone. Therfore be no?t so balde Ãat no slike tales be talde, But halde Ã¾e stille als stane. Ãou art yonge and I am alde, Slike werkis yf I do walde, Ãase games fra me are gane. 20. Therfore, telle me in priuite whos is Ã¾e childe Ã¾ou is with nowe? Sertis, Ã¾er sall non witte but we, I drede Ã¾e law als wele as Ã¾ou. Mar. Nowe grete God of his myght, Ãat all may dresse and dight, Mekely to Ã¾e I bowe! Rewe on Ã¾is wery wight, Ãat in his herte might light Ãe soth to ken and trowe. 21. Jos. Who had thy maydenhede Marie? has Ã¾ou oght mynde. Mar. For suth, I am a mayden clene. Jos. Nay Ã¾ou spekis now agayne kynde; Slike Ã¾ing myght neuere naman of mene. A maiden to be with childe, Ãase werkis fra Ã¾e ar wilde, Sho is not borne I wene. Mar. Joseph, yhe ar begiled, With synne was I neuer filid, Goddis sande is on me sene. 22. Jos. Goddis sande! yha Marie! God helpe, Bot certis! Ã¾at childe was neuere oures two. But woman kynde gif Ã¾at list yhelpe, Yhitt walde Ã¾ei naman wiste Ã¾er wo. Mar. Sertis, it is Goddis sande, Ãat sall I neuer ga fra. Jos. Yha! Marie, drawe thyn hande, For forther ?itt will I frande, I trowe not it be swa. 23. Ãe soth fra me gif Ã¾at Ã¾ou layne Ãe childe bering may Ã¾ou no?t hyde, But sitte stille here tille I come agayne, Me bus an erand here beside. Mar. Now, grete God! be you wisse, And mende you of your mysse, Of me, what so betyde. Als he is kyng of blysse, Sende yhou som seand of Ã¾is, In truth Ã¾at ye might bide. [Joseph goes out again. 24. Jos. Nowe, lord God! Ã¾at all Ã¾ing may At thine owne will bothe do and dresse, Wisse me now som redy way To walk here in Ã¾is wildirnesse. Bot or I passe Ã¾is hill, Do with me what God will, Owther more or lesse, Here bus me bide full stille Till I haue slepid my fille. Myn hert so heuy it is. [Sleeps. [Enter the angel Gabriel.] 25. Ang. Waken, Joseph! and take bettir kepe To Marie, Ã¾at is Ã¾i felawe fest. Jos. A! I am full werie, lefe late me slepe, For-wandered and walked in Ã¾is forest. Ang. Rise vppe! and slepe na mare, Ãou makist her herte full sare. Ãat loues Ã¾e alther best. Jos. We! now es Ã¾is a farly fare, For to be cached bathe here and Ã¾are, And nowhere may haue rest. 26. Say, what arte Ã¾ou? telle me this thyng. Ang. I Gabriell, Goddis aungell full euen, Ãat has tane Marie to my kepyng, And sente es Ã¾e to say with steuen, In lele wedlak Ã¾ou lede Ã¾e, Leffe hir no?t, I forbid Ã¾e, Na syn of hir Ã¾ou neuen. But till hir fast Ã¾ou spede Ã¾e, And of hir noght Ã¾ou drede Ã¾e, It is Goddis sande of heuen. 27. The childe Ã¾at sall be borne of her, Itt is consayued of Ã¾e haly gast. Alle joie and blisse Ã¾an sall be aftir, And to al mankynde nowe althir mast. Jesus his name Ã¾ou calle, For slike happe sall hym fall Als Ã¾ou sall se in haste. His pepull saff he sall Of euyllis and angris all, Ãat Ã¾ei ar nowe enbraste. 28. Jos. And is this soth, aungell, Ã¾ou saise? Ang. Yha! and Ã¾is to taken right, Wende forthe to Marie thy wiffe alwayse, Brynge hir to Bedlem Ã¾is ilke nyght. Ther sall a childe borne be, Goddis sone of heuen is hee, And man ay mast of myght. Jos. Nowe lorde god! full wele is me, That euyr Ã¾at I Ã¾is sight suld see, I was neuer ar so light. 29. For for I walde hir Ã¾us refused, And sakles blame Ã¾at ay was clere, Me bus pray hir halde me excused, Als som men dose with full gud chere. [He re-enters his house. Saie, Marie wiffe, how fares Ã¾ou? Mar. Ãe bettir sir, for yhou. Why stande yhe Ã¾are? come nere. Jos. My bakke fayne wolde I bowe, And aske fo[r]gifnesse nowe, Wiste I Ã¾ou wolde me here. 30. Mar. Forgiffnesse sir! late be! for shame, Slike wordis suld all gud women lakke. Jos. Yha, Marie, I am to blame, For wordis lang are I to Ã¾e spak. But gadir same now all oure gere; Slike poure wede as we were, And prike Ã¾am in a pak. Till Bedlem bus me it bere, For litill thyng will women dere. Helpe vp nowe on my bak!
